In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

Certainly! Below is the definition of the `clean_column` function in Julia that does what you've described:

```julia
function clean_column(col::String)
    # Lowercase the column name
    col = lowercase(col)
    
    # Strip leading and trailing whitespaces
    col = strip(col)
    
    # Replace spaces and hyphens with underscores
    col = replace(col, " " => "_")
    col = replace(col, "-" => "_")
    
    return col
end
```

This function takes a `String` representing a column name as input and returns the cleaned version of that string. It first lowers the case, then strips any leading or trailing whitespace, and finally replaces spaces and hyphens with underscores.

You can use this function like so:

```julia
julia> clean_column("My Column")
"my_column"
```

This will return "my_column" as expected.
